Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Low Latency Video Rate Hyperspectral Imaging and Analysis for In Vivo Imaging

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Faris, Gregory
Proposal Number: 1511082

The proposed project, if successful, would represent a significant technological advance in support of current trends to increasingly use dyes and markers to aid visualization of critical tissue structures, improve biopsy selection, and lower adverse events in surgery and endoscopic procedures.

This proposal project will develop new technology for very high speed hyperspectral imaging including on-the-fly processing of acquired data for spectral computation and spectral decomposition within the period of one video frame (1/30 second). This project will extend the technology for real-time, full-frame Fourier transform spectroscopy based on a 2D-imaging, reference-scanning Michelson interferometer coupled to a high-speed camera with the data sent via a high-speed parallel optical fiber connection. The project will impact education through training of two post-doctoral and several undergraduate students (through SRI's REU program which the PI co-directs). The project will also support SRI's unique mission in making connections between academia and industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Imaging methods are widely used to detect, diagnose, and monitor treatment of disease as well as to improve the understanding of biological factors that affect human health and our environment. Because the human body and other biological systems are so complex, there is strong interest in collecting more information during imaging. This project advances optical imaging methods (i.e., imaging using light) to gain more information such as the presence of disease-related proteins or metabolic changes, either in the living body (called in vivo imaging) or in biopsy samples.

The imaging method we use is called hyperspectral imaging. In contrast to conventional color imaging that collects only red, green and blue colors, hyperspectral imaging collects a very large number colors, around 100 colors or wavelengths, in each image. With this many colors, more information can be gleaned about biological and metabolic processes in the imaged region either directly or through the addition of stains or contrast agents that accentuate differences between tissue types or between healthy and diseased tissue. A particular emphasis of this research is on speed. With measurement of many more colors or wavelengths, there is much more data to collect than in a simple color image. We are working to minimize the amount of time to collect and process these large datasets based on image collection and computer processing that occurs in parallel (multiple operations simultaneously).

This project contributed to training the next generation of scientists. This hands-on research training helps the nation by developing the workforce in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM). The younger scientists benefit from learning important skills, developing a broader understanding of science, and helping make better informed decisions about careers goals and paths to reach those goals. This project supported three Research Experiences for Undergraduate (REU) students, two recently-graduated research assistants, and one postdoctoral associate. The REU program is also supported by the National Science Foundation with the explicit purpose of supporting undergraduate research opportunities such as these.

In the longer term, this research can provide broader impacts beyond the field of optical imaging. For example, the methods we are developing could assist in detection and diagnosis of cancer or in providing a better view for surgeons during an operation.
